title: How to Make Ric Rac Flowers

steps.headline: Cut two strips of ric rack.
steps.description: Start with 10 to 12 inches (25.5 to 30.5 centimeters) for a small rose. Use 16 to 17 inches (40.5 to 43 centimeters) for a larger one. Keep in mind that you can always trim off the excess ric rac. The wider the ric rac, the bigger the rose will be. If you want a small rose, use thin ric rac. If you want a larger rose, use wider ric rac. Your rose can be any color you want. Pink, red, and white are great choices, but why not try baby blue, light purple, or even rainbow?

steps.headline: Lay pieces side by side so that they mirror one another.
steps.description: Overlap the ends and secure them with a drop of hot glue. The inner, scooped parts of the curves should be facing each other. The outer, bumpy part of the curves should be facing out.

steps.headline: "Braid" the ric rac strips together.
steps.description: Pull the upper strip under the bottom one. Keep it straight and don't let it twist. The strips should naturally lock together at the curve. Continue "braiding" the strip to the other end, then secure it with another drop of hot glue.

steps.headline: Sew down one side for extra support.
steps.description: This is not completely necessary, but it will help hold the ric rac together during the next step. Do not sew right down the middle of the ric rac strip. Instead, sew it to the left or two the right of the strip. Make sure that you are catching both strips as you sew, however. Use a thread color that matches your ric rac.

steps.headline: Start rolling it up.
steps.description: Pinch one end of the ric rac strip, then start rolling it tightly towards the other end. Add a drop of hot glue every inch (2.5 centimeters) or so. This will help hold your rose together and prevent it from popping out when you go to finish it. Don't use too much glue. Less is more.

steps.headline: Keep rolling until the rose is the size you want.
steps.description: When it's the size you want, add a final drop of hot glue on the ric rac, and press it down. Make sure that you have about 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) of ric rac left for tucking under the rose.

steps.headline: Tuck the tail under the rose and hot glue it in place.
steps.description: Trim off any excess ric rac with a pair of fabric scissors. If you sewed down the ric rac strip earlier, make sure the stitched part facing towards the bottom. This is important. If it is on the top, you won't be able to open the rose.

steps.headline: Hot glue circle of felt to back, if desired.
steps.description: This is not completely necessary, but it will give your rose a nicer finish. Trace the bottom of the rose onto a scrap of matching felt. Cut the circle out, then hot glue it to the bottom of the rose. Consider gluing some silk or fabric leaves to the bottom of the flower. This will make it look even more rose like. Do this before you add the felt circle.

steps.headline: Open petals for a fuller, more realistic look.
steps.description: You can leave your rose closed up, or you can gently pull the petals down. This will give it a fuller, more realistic look. Start from outside and work your way in. Consider leaving the center petals closed.

steps.headline: Cut two circles out of felt.
steps.description: Trace a circle onto a sheet of felt, then cut it out. Use the circle to trace a second one, and cut it out as well. Plan on making the circles about 2 inches (5 centimeters) across. They do not have to be perfect, but they need to match up. The color of the felt does not matter, but it would be best if it matches your ric rac. This way, if you get any gaps, they won't be as obvious.

steps.headline: Wrap some ric rac around the outer edge of the first circle.
steps.description: Make sure that the outer loops stick out over the edge of the circle, and the inner loops are inside the circle. Set the other circle aside for now.

steps.headline: Stitch the ric rac down.
steps.description: Use a needle and thread to secure the bottom loops to the felt circle. If you don't know how to sew, or if you don't have any needles or thread on hand, you can use tiny drops of hot glue instead. If you want to make a dahlia-type flower, gather the ric rac as you sew it.

steps.headline: Lay down another row of ric rac and stitch it in place.
steps.description: Let the outer loops overlap the inner loops of the first row. Again, stitch the bottom loops in place. Don't stitch the outer loops. This will allow them to flare out and look like petals.

steps.headline: Continue laying down more rows of ric rac.
steps.description: Make sure that each row overlaps the previous one slightly. As you get towards the center, the ric rac may start to buckle, which is fine. Many flowers get fuller and bushier towards the center!

steps.headline: Trim off the excess ric rac and stitch it down.
steps.description: When you get to the center, cut off the excess ric rac with a pair of fabric scissors. Stitch it down using 2 to 3 stitches, then tie the knot on the back.

steps.headline: Hot glue an embellishment to the center.
steps.description: You can use a button for a rustic look, or a pretty rhinestone for something fancier. Make sure that it is big enough to cover any visible felt. If you are using a button, consider sewing on instead. This will give you a nice, rustic-chic look.

steps.headline: Hot glue the other felt circle to the back of the flower.
steps.description: This will cover up the stitching and give your flower extra support. If you wish to use these flowers as hair clips, cut a slit in the second felt circle. Open and slide a hair clip through it. Hot glue the circle and the top of the clip to the back of the flower.

text: Making Ric Rac Roses Cut two strips of ric rack. Start with 10 to 12 inches (25.5 to 30.5 centimeters) for a small rose. Use 16 to 17 inches (40.5 to 43 centimeters) for a larger one. Keep in mind that you can always trim off the excess ric rac. The wider the ric rac, the bigger the rose will be. If you want a small rose, use thin ric rac. If you want a larger rose, use wider ric rac. Your rose can be any color you want. Pink, red, and white are great choices, but why not try baby blue, light purple, or even rainbow? Lay pieces side by side so that they mirror one another. Overlap the ends and secure them with a drop of hot glue. The inner, scooped parts of the curves should be facing each other. The outer, bumpy part of the curves should be facing out. "Braid" the ric rac strips together. Pull the upper strip under the bottom one. Keep it straight and don't let it twist. The strips should naturally lock together at the curve. Continue "braiding" the strip to the other end, then secure it with another drop of hot glue. Sew down one side for extra support. This is not completely necessary, but it will help hold the ric rac together during the next step. Do not sew right down the middle of the ric rac strip. Instead, sew it to the left or two the right of the strip. Make sure that you are catching both strips as you sew, however. Use a thread color that matches your ric rac. Start rolling it up. Pinch one end of the ric rac strip, then start rolling it tightly towards the other end. Add a drop of hot glue every inch (2.5 centimeters) or so. This will help hold your rose together and prevent it from popping out when you go to finish it. Don't use too much glue. Less is more. Keep rolling until the rose is the size you want. When it's the size you want, add a final drop of hot glue on the ric rac, and press it down. Make sure that you have about 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) of ric rac left for tucking under the rose. Tuck the tail under the rose and hot glue it in place. Trim off any excess ric rac with a pair of fabric scissors. If you sewed down the ric rac strip earlier, make sure the stitched part facing towards the bottom. This is important. If it is on the top, you won't be able to open the rose. Hot glue circle of felt to back, if desired. This is not completely necessary, but it will give your rose a nicer finish. Trace the bottom of the rose onto a scrap of matching felt. Cut the circle out, then hot glue it to the bottom of the rose. Consider gluing some silk or fabric leaves to the bottom of the flower. This will make it look even more rose like. Do this before you add the felt circle. Open petals for a fuller, more realistic look. You can leave your rose closed up, or you can gently pull the petals down. This will give it a fuller, more realistic look. Start from outside and work your way in. Consider leaving the center petals closed. Making Button Flowers Cut two circles out of felt. Trace a circle onto a sheet of felt, then cut it out. Use the circle to trace a second one, and cut it out as well. Plan on making the circles about 2 inches (5 centimeters) across. They do not have to be perfect, but they need to match up. The color of the felt does not matter, but it would be best if it matches your ric rac. This way, if you get any gaps, they won't be as obvious. Wrap some ric rac around the outer edge of the first circle. Make sure that the outer loops stick out over the edge of the circle, and the inner loops are inside the circle. Set the other circle aside for now. Stitch the ric rac down. Use a needle and thread to secure the bottom loops to the felt circle. If you don't know how to sew, or if you don't have any needles or thread on hand, you can use tiny drops of hot glue instead. If you want to make a dahlia-type flower, gather the ric rac as you sew it. Lay down another row of ric rac and stitch it in place. Let the outer loops overlap the inner loops of the first row. Again, stitch the bottom loops in place. Don't stitch the outer loops. This will allow them to flare out and look like petals. Continue laying down more rows of ric rac. Make sure that each row overlaps the previous one slightly. As you get towards the center, the ric rac may start to buckle, which is fine. Many flowers get fuller and bushier towards the center! Trim off the excess ric rac and stitch it down. When you get to the center, cut off the excess ric rac with a pair of fabric scissors. Stitch it down using 2 to 3 stitches, then tie the knot on the back. Hot glue an embellishment to the center. You can use a button for a rustic look, or a pretty rhinestone for something fancier. Make sure that it is big enough to cover any visible felt. If you are using a button, consider sewing on instead. This will give you a nice, rustic-chic look. Hot glue the other felt circle to the back of the flower. This will cover up the stitching and give your flower extra support. If you wish to use these flowers as hair clips, cut a slit in the second felt circle. Open and slide a hair clip through it. Hot glue the circle and the top of the clip to the back of the flower.
sentences: Making Ric Rac Roses Cut two strips of ric rack.
Start with 10 to 12 inches (25.5 to 30.5 centimeters) for a small rose.
Use 16 to 17 inches (40.5 to 43 centimeters) for a larger one.
Keep in mind that you can always trim off the excess ric rac.
The wider the ric rac, the bigger the rose will be.
If you want a small rose, use thin ric rac.
If you want a larger rose, use wider ric rac.
Your rose can be any color you want.
Pink, red, and white are great choices, but why not try baby blue, light purple, or even rainbow?
Lay pieces side by side so that they mirror one another.
Overlap the ends and secure them with a drop of hot glue.
The inner, scooped parts of the curves should be facing each other.
The outer, bumpy part of the curves should be facing out.
"Braid" the ric rac strips together.
Pull the upper strip under the bottom one.
Keep it straight and don't let it twist.
The strips should naturally lock together at the curve.
Continue "braiding" the strip to the other end, then secure it with another drop of hot glue.
Sew down one side for extra support.
This is not completely necessary, but it will help hold the ric rac together during the next step.
Do not sew right down the middle of the ric rac strip.
Instead, sew it to the left or two the right of the strip.
Make sure that you are catching both strips as you sew, however.
Use a thread color that matches your ric rac.
Start rolling it up.
Pinch one end of the ric rac strip, then start rolling it tightly towards the other end.
Add a drop of hot glue every inch (2.5 centimeters) or so.
This will help hold your rose together and prevent it from popping out when you go to finish it.
Don't use too much glue.
Less is more.
Keep rolling until the rose is the size you want.
When it's the size you want, add a final drop of hot glue on the ric rac, and press it down.
Make sure that you have about 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) of ric rac left for tucking under the rose.
Tuck the tail under the rose and hot glue it in place.
Trim off any excess ric rac with a pair of fabric scissors.
If you sewed down the ric rac strip earlier, make sure the stitched part facing towards the bottom.
This is important.
If it is on the top, you won't be able to open the rose.
Hot glue circle of felt to back, if desired.
This is not completely necessary, but it will give your rose a nicer finish.
Trace the bottom of the rose onto a scrap of matching felt.
Cut the circle out, then hot glue it to the bottom of the rose.
Consider gluing some silk or fabric leaves to the bottom of the flower.
This will make it look even more rose like.
Do this before you add the felt circle.
Open petals for a fuller, more realistic look.
You can leave your rose closed up, or you can gently pull the petals down.
This will give it a fuller, more realistic look.
Start from outside and work your way in.
Consider leaving the center petals closed.
Making Button Flowers Cut two circles out of felt.
Trace a circle onto a sheet of felt, then cut it out.
Use the circle to trace a second one, and cut it out as well.
Plan on making the circles about 2 inches (5 centimeters) across.
They do not have to be perfect, but they need to match up.
The color of the felt does not matter, but it would be best if it matches your ric rac.
This way, if you get any gaps, they won't be as obvious.
Wrap some ric rac around the outer edge of the first circle.
Make sure that the outer loops stick out over the edge of the circle, and the inner loops are inside the circle.
Set the other circle aside for now.
Stitch the ric rac down.
Use a needle and thread to secure the bottom loops to the felt circle.
If you don't know how to sew, or if you don't have any needles or thread on hand, you can use tiny drops of hot glue instead.
If you want to make a dahlia-type flower, gather the ric rac as you sew it.
Lay down another row of ric rac and stitch it in place.
Let the outer loops overlap the inner loops of the first row.
Again, stitch the bottom loops in place.
Don't stitch the outer loops.
This will allow them to flare out and look like petals.
Continue laying down more rows of ric rac.
Make sure that each row overlaps the previous one slightly.
As you get towards the center, the ric rac may start to buckle, which is fine.
Many flowers get fuller and bushier towards the center!
Trim off the excess ric rac and stitch it down.
When you get to the center, cut off the excess ric rac with a pair of fabric scissors.
Stitch it down using 2 to 3 stitches, then tie the knot on the back.
Hot glue an embellishment to the center.
You can use a button for a rustic look, or a pretty rhinestone for something fancier.
Make sure that it is big enough to cover any visible felt.
If you are using a button, consider sewing on instead.
This will give you a nice, rustic-chic look.
Hot glue the other felt circle to the back of the flower.
This will cover up the stitching and give your flower extra support.
If you wish to use these flowers as hair clips, cut a slit in the second felt circle.
Open and slide a hair clip through it.
Hot glue the circle and the top of the clip to the back of the flower.
